[[Liudolf, Duke of Swabia]] Edith of England(lang-angĒadgȳð) (910 26 January 946), also speltEadgythordgyth, was the daughter ofEdward the Elder, and the wife ofOtto I, Holy Roman Emperor.
article.heading: Life
article.paragraph: Edith was born to the reigning English kingEdward the Elderby his second wife,lffld, wife of Edward the Elderlffld, and hence was granddaughter ofAlfred the Great. Nothing is known of her until in order to seal an alliance between two Saxon kingdoms, her half-brother, KingAthelstan of England, sent two of his sisters (Eadgyth andEadgifu of Wessex) to Germany, instructing the Duke of Saxony (laterOtto I, Holy Roman Emperor) to choose whichever one pleased him best. Otto chose Edith and married her in 930. The remaining sister Algiva or Adiva was married to a "king near the Jupiter mountains" (theAlps). The precise identity of the husband of this sister is debated.

In 936Henry the FowlerKing Henry Iof Germany died and his eldest son, Eadgyth's husband, was crowned atAachenasOtto I, Holy Roman EmperorKing Otto I. There is a surviving report of the ceremony byWidukind of Corveywhich makes no mention of his wife having been crowned at this point, but according toThietmar of Merseburg's chronicle Eadgyth was neverthelessAnointinganointedas queen, albeit in a separate ceremony. As queen, Eadgyth undertook the usual state duties of "First lady": when she turns up in the records it is generally in connection with gifts to the state'sList of Imperial abbeysfavoured monasteriesor memorials to holy women andsaints. In this respect she seems to have been more diligent than her now widowed and subsequently sainted mother-in-lawMatilda of RingelheimQueen Matildawhose own charitable activities only achieve a single recorded mention from the period of Eadgyth's time as queen. There was probably rivalry between theOrder of Saint BenedictBenedictine:de:MauritiusklosterMonastery of St Mauricefounded atMagdeburgby Otto and Eadgyth in 937, a year after coming to the throne and Matilda's foundation atQuedlinburg Abbey, intended by her as a memorial to her husband, the lateHenry the FowlerKing Henry I.
Eadgyth accompanied her husband on his travels, though not during battles. She spent the hostilities of 939 atLorsch Abbey

Like her brother, Athelstan, Edith was devoted to the cult ofOswald of NorthumbriaSaint Oswaldand was instrumental in introducing this cult into Germany after her marriage to the emperor. Her lasting influence may have caused certain monasteries and churches inDuchy of SaxonySaxonyto be dedicated to this saint.Cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/science/2010/jan/20/alfred-great-granddaughter-remains-wessexKennedyMaev20 January 2010Remains of Alfred the Great's granddaughter returned / Coming home: the Saxon queen lost for 1,000 years520 January 2010LondonThe Guardian
Eadgyth's death at a relatively young age, in her early thirties, was unexpected.
article.heading: Children
Tomb
article.paragraph: Her tomb is located in theCathedral of Magdeburg. A lead coffin inside a stone sarcophagus with her name on it was found and opened in 2008 by archaeologists during work on the building. An inscription recorded that it was the body of Eadgyth, reburied in 1510. It was examined in 2009, then brought toBristol, England, for tests in 2010. ProfessorMark Horton (archaeologist)Mark HortonofUniversity of BristolBristol Universitysaid that "this may prove to be the oldest complete remains of an English royal." The investigations at Bristol, applyingTechnetium-99misotopetests on tooth enamel, checked whether she was born and brought up inWessexandMercia, as written history has indicated.Cite webhttp://web.archive.org/web/20100123012854/http://news.discovery.com/archaeology/english-princess-bones.htmlDiscovery NewsSatterRaphael G.20 January 2010Bones of early English princess found in Germany21 January 2010Retrieved from Internet Archive 14 February 2014.Testing on the bones revealed that they are the remains of Eadgyth, from study made of the enamel of the teeth in her upper jaw.German cathedral bones 'are Saxon queen Eadgyth, BBC News, 16 June 2010Retrieved from Internet Archive 14 February 2014.Testing of the enamel revealed that the individual entombed at Magdeburg had spent time as a youth in thechalkyuplands ofWessex.Remains of first king of England's sister found in German cathedral, The Guardian, 17 June 2010

"Tests on these isotopes can give a precise record of where the person lived up to the age of 14," notedThe Timesof London in its story on the testing. "In this case they showed that the woman in the casket had spent the first years of her life drinking water that came from springs on thechalkhills of southern England. This matched exactly the historical records of Eadgyths early life."The Times, Simon de Bruxelles, 17 June 2010

The bones "are the oldest surviving remains of an English royal burial," Bristol University announced in a press release.Bones confirmed as those of Saxon Princess Eadgyth, University of Bristol, 17 June 2010
Following the tests the bones were re-interred in Magdeburg Cathedral on 22 October 2010.Knigin Editha im Magdeburger Dom bestattetin:Spiegel Onlinevom 22. Oktober 2010
